abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory. Most outcomes will be sustained and will have
            a long-run impact of the development of respective labor,
            social assistance, and training institutions in the country.
            With project sustainability likely. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are adjudged satisfactory overall. The
            main lessons include the following: The information
            generated on the efficiency of labor programs by the
            management information system should not be used in a
            punitive manner but to help offices redirect resources in a
            more cost-effective manner. It is also difficult to
            implement an MIS program if client records are not
            automated. Implementation of an automation subcomponent was
            complicated by uncoordinated automation at the local level,
            changes in ministry staff due to changes in government,
            changes in employment and social assistance legislation,
            decentralization of social assistance offices, and
            development of the national labor office. Information was
            hindered by the fact that existing statistical agencies are
            coming from a history of central planning and unused to
            being client responsive. Other obstacles included
            organizational changes, political interference with staff,
            competition for automation staff, and delays in contract
            compliance. Positive features included stakeholder
            involvement and openness, the involvement of nongovernmental
            organizations, and the participation of an excellent
            technical assistance contractor.
